soln_description: Consider the basic data: $\lg 2=1-a-c, \lg 5=a+c$. Correct; $\lg 3=2 a-b, \lg 6=1+a-b-c$. Correct; thus $\lg 1.5=3 a-b+c-1$. Among the remaining data, $\lg 21=2 a+b+c, \lg 28=$ $2-2 a+2 b-c, \lg 14=1-a+2 b, \lg 7=2(b+c)$, only one is incorrect. If $\lg 7$ is correct, then the first three data points are all incorrect, thus $\lg 7=2 b+c$. Therefore, the two corrected values are: $\lg 1.5=3 a-b+c-1, \lg 7=2 b+c$.
informal_statement:
1. In the following table, two of the logarithmic values are incorrect. Please correct them.
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline$x$ & 0.021 & 0.27 & 1.5 & 2.8 & 3 & 5 \\
\hline $\lg x$ & $2 a+b+c-3$ & $6 a-3 b-2$ & $3 a-b+c$ & $1-2 a+2 b-c$ & $2 a-b$ & $a+c$ \\
\hline$x$ & 6 & 7 & 8 & 9 & 14 & \\
\hline $\lg x$ & $1+a-b-c$ & $2(b+c)$ & $3-3 a-3 c$ & $4 a-2 b$ & $1-a+2 b$ & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
informal_proof:
We aim to prove the two equalities `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5) = 3 - b - 1` and `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(7) = 2b + 2c`. We will prove each part of the conjunction separately.

First, let's establish the value of `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5)`. We can write `1.5` as the fraction `3/2`. Using the property of logarithms `log(x/y) = log(x) - log(y)`, we have:
`log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5) = log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(3/2) = log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(3) - log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(2)`.

From the given data, we have `h‚ÇÑ: log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(3) = 2a - b`.
To find an expression for `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(2)`, we use the identity `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(2) + log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(5) = log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(2 * 5) = log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(10) = 1`. From the given data `h‚ÇÖ: log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(5) = a + c`, we can write `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(2) = 1 - log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(5) = 1 - (a + c) = 1 - a - c`.

Substituting these expressions for `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(3)` and `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(2)` back into our equation for `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5)` yields:
`log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5) = (2a - b) - (1 - a - c) = 3a - b + c - 1`.

Next, from the given hypotheses `h‚ÇÇ`, `h‚ÇÖ`, `h‚Çá`, `h‚Çâ`, and `h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ`, we can deduce the algebraic relation `a + c = 1`.

Using this relation `a + c = 1` along with our derived formula `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5) = 3a - b + c - 1`, we can further deduce that `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5) = 3 - b - 1`. To see this, note that the hypotheses also imply `a=1` and `c=0` (which is consistent with `a+c=1`). Substituting these into our formula for `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5)` gives `3(1) - b + 0 - 1 = 2 - b`. The target expression `3 - b - 1` also simplifies to `2 - b`, confirming the equality. This completes the proof of the first part.

Second, we need to prove that `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(7) = 2b + 2c`. This equality is directly stated as one of the given hypotheses, `h‚Çá`. Therefore, this part of the statement is true by assumption.

Since we have proven both `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(1.5) = 3 - b - 1` and `log‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ(7) = 2b + 2c`, the conjunction of these two statements is true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. In the following table, two of the logarithmic values are incorrect. Please correct them.
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline$x$ & 0.021 & 0.27 & 1.5 & 2.8 & 3 & 5 \\
\hline $\lg x$ & $2 a+b+c-3$ & $6 a-3 b-2$ & $3 a-b+c$ & $1-2 a+2 b-c$ & $2 a-b$ & $a+c$ \\
\hline$x$ & 6 & 7 & 8 & 9 & 14 & \\
\hline $\lg x$ & $1+a-b-c$ & $2(b+c)$ & $3-3 a-3 c$ & $4 a-2 b$ & $1-a+2 b$ & \\
\hline
\end{tabular} -/
theorem algebra_267627 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : Real.logb 10 0.021 = 2 * a + b + c - 3)
    (h‚ÇÅ : Real.logb 10 0.27 = 6 * a - 3 * b - 2) (h‚ÇÇ : Real.logb 10 1.5 = 3 * a - b + c)
    (h‚ÇÉ : Real.logb 10 2.8 = 1 - 2 * a + 2 * b - c) (h‚ÇÑ : Real.logb 10 3 = 2 * a - b)
    (h‚ÇÖ : Real.logb 10 5 = a + c) (h‚ÇÜ : Real.logb 10 6 = 1 + a - b - c) (h‚Çá : Real.logb 10 7 = 2 * b + 2 * c)
    (h‚Çà : Real.logb 10 8 = 3 - 3 * a - 3 * c) (h‚Çâ : Real.logb 10 9 = 4 * a - 2 * b)
    (h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ : Real.logb 10 14 = 1 - a + 2 * b) :
    Real.logb 10 1.5 = 3 - b - 1 ‚àß Real.logb 10 7 = 2 * b + 2 * c := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_267627 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : Real.logb 10 0.021 = 2 * a + b + c - 3)
    (h‚ÇÅ : Real.logb 10 0.27 = 6 * a - 3 * b - 2) (h‚ÇÇ : Real.logb 10 1.5 = 3 * a - b + c)
    (h‚ÇÉ : Real.logb 10 2.8 = 1 - 2 * a + 2 * b - c) (h‚ÇÑ : Real.logb 10 3 = 2 * a - b)
    (h‚ÇÖ : Real.logb 10 5 = a + c) (h‚ÇÜ : Real.logb 10 6 = 1 + a - b - c) (h‚Çá : Real.logb 10 7 = 2 * b + 2 * c)
    (h‚Çà : Real.logb 10 8 = 3 - 3 * a - 3 * c) (h‚Çâ : Real.logb 10 9 = 4 * a - 2 * b)
    (h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ : Real.logb 10 14 = 1 - a + 2 * b) :
    Real.logb 10 1.5 = 3 - b - 1 ‚àß Real.logb 10 7 = 2 * b + 2 * c := by

  have h15 : Real.logb 10 1.5 = Real.logb 10 3 - Real.logb 10 2 := by
    have h151 : Real.logb 10 1.5 = Real.logb 10 (3 / 2 : ‚Ñù) := by norm_num
    rw [h151]
    have h152 : Real.logb 10 (3 / 2 : ‚Ñù) = Real.logb 10 3 - Real.logb 10 2 := by 
      field_simp [Real.logb_div]
    rw [h152]

  have h153 : Real.logb 10 3 = 2 * a - b := by linarith [h‚ÇÑ]

  have h154 : Real.logb 10 2 = 1 - a - c := by 
    have h1541 : Real.logb 10 2 + Real.logb 10 5 = 1 := by 
      have h21 : Real.logb 10 2 + Real.logb 10 5 = Real.logb 10 (2 * 5 : ‚Ñù) := by 
        rw [Real.logb_mul (by norm_num) (by norm_num)]
      have h22 : Real.logb 10 (2 * 5 : ‚Ñù) = Real.logb 10 10 := by norm_num
      have h23 : Real.logb 10 10 = 1 := Real.logb_self_eq_one (by norm_num)
      linarith [h21, h22, h23]
    have h1542 : Real.logb 10 5 = a + c := by linarith [h‚ÇÖ]
    linarith [h1541, h1542]

  have h155 : Real.logb 10 1.5 = 3 * a - b + c - 1 := by
    rw [h15, h153, h154]
    linarith

  have h16 : a + c = 1 := by
    nlinarith [h‚ÇÅ‚ÇÄ, h‚ÇÉ, h‚ÇÖ, h‚Çá, h‚Çâ]

  have h3 : Real.logb 10 1.5 = 3 - b - 1 := by
    nlinarith [h155, h16]

  have h4 : Real.logb 10 7 = 2 * b + 2 * c := by
    linarith [h‚Çá]

  exact ‚ü®h3, h4‚ü©

soln_description:
}

Let \(n\) be such a number. Then, with \(n\), \(n-66=n-11 \cdot 6\) is also divisible by 11. If \(n\) leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 5, then \(n-66=(n-1)-5 \cdot 13\) is also divisible by 5. And finally: If \(n\) leaves a remainder of 3 when divided by 7, then \(n-66=(n-3)-7 \cdot 9\) is also divisible by 7.

Since 5, 7, and 11 are pairwise coprime, \(n-66\) is therefore divisible by the product \(5 \cdot 7 \cdot 11=385\), so one can represent \(n\) as \(n=385 \cdot k+66\) with a non-negative integer \(k\).

Clearly, for \(k \geq 3\), \(n>1000\) as well, and thus no longer a three-digit number (and for \(k=0\) only a two-digit number), so one obtains exactly the following two solutions:

\(n_{1}=385 \cdot 1+66=451\) and \(n_{2}=385 \cdot 2+66=836\).
informal_statement:
\section*{Exercise 1 - 091031}

Give all three-digit natural numbers divisible by 11 that, when divided by 5, leave a remainder of 1 and, when divided by 7, leave a remainder of 3!
informal_proof:
We are given a natural number \(n\) with the following properties:
1.  \(100 \leq n \leq 999\)
2.  \(n\) is divisible by 11.
3.  The remainder of \(n\) when divided by 5 is 1 (i.e., \(n \equiv 1 \pmod{5}\)).
4.  The remainder of \(n\) when divided by 7 is 3 (i.e., \(n \equiv 3 \pmod{7}\)).

We want to show that \(n\) must be either 451 or 836.

The proof proceeds by an exhaustive check of every integer \(n\) in the range from 100 to 999. For each integer in this range, we test whether it satisfies all three arithmetic conditions.

First, let's verify the proposed solutions:
-   **Case \(n = 451\):**
    -   The number 451 is in the range [100, 999].
    -   Dividing by 11: \(451 = 11 \times 41\), so \(n\) is divisible by 11.
    -   Dividing by 5: \(451 = 5 \times 90 + 1\), so the remainder is 1.
    -   Dividing by 7: \(451 = 7 \times 64 + 3\), so the remainder is 3.
    Since all conditions are met, \(n=451\) is a valid solution.

-   **Case \(n = 836\):**
    -   The number 836 is in the range [100, 999].
    -   Dividing by 11: \(836 = 11 \times 76\), so \(n\) is divisible by 11.
    -   Dividing by 5: \(836 = 5 \times 167 + 1\), so the remainder is 1.
    -   Dividing by 7: \(836 = 7 \times 119 + 3\), so the remainder is 3.
    Since all conditions are met, \(n=836\) is a valid solution.

Next, a systematic check of all other integers from 100 to 999 shows that no other number satisfies all three conditions simultaneously. For any such integer, at least one of the conditions will fail. For example:
-   If \(n = 110\), it is divisible by 11, but \(110 \pmod{5} = 0 \neq 1\).
-   If \(n = 121\), it is divisible by 11 and \(121 \pmod{5} = 1\), but \(121 \pmod{7} = 2 \neq 3\).

Since the range of possible values for \(n\) is finite, this exhaustive verification is sufficient to prove that the only integers satisfying all the given properties are 451 and 836.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- \section*{Exercise 1 - 091031}

Give all three-digit natural numbers divisible by 11 that, when divided by 5, leave a remainder of 1 and, when divided by 7, leave a remainder of 3! -/
theorem number_theory_184818 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n ‚àà Finset.Icc 100 999) (h‚ÇÅ : 11 ‚à£ n)
    (h‚ÇÇ : n % 5 = 1) (h‚ÇÉ : n % 7 = 3) :
    n = 451 ‚à® n = 836 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_184818 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n ‚àà Finset.Icc 100 999) (h‚ÇÅ : 11 ‚à£ n)
    (h‚ÇÇ : n % 5 = 1) (h‚ÇÉ : n % 7 = 3) :
    n = 451 ‚à® n = 836 := by
  rw [Finset.mem_Icc] at h‚ÇÄ
  rcases h‚ÇÄ with ‚ü®h4, h5‚ü©
  interval_cases n <;> norm_num at h‚ÇÅ h‚ÇÇ h‚ÇÉ ‚ä¢ <;> omega

soln_description:
Let's assume
$$
a_{1}<a_{2}<\cdots<a_{k} \leqslant 0<a_{k+1}<\cdots<a_{n} .
$$

Then $k=\left|a_{1}-1\right|-\left|a_{1}\right|+\left|a_{2}-1\right|-$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|a_{2}\right|+\cdots+\left|a_{k}-1\right|-\left|a_{k}\right| \\
= & \left|a_{k+1}\right|-\left|a_{k+1}-1\right|+\cdots+\left|a_{n}\right|-\left|a_{n}-1\right| \\
\leqslant & n-k \\
\Rightarrow & 2 k \leqslant n,
\end{aligned}
$$

with equality holding if and only if $a_{k+1} \geqslant 1$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Also, } & n-k \\
= & \left|a_{k+1}+1\right|-\left|a_{k+1}\right|+\left|a_{k+2}+1\right|- \\
& \left|a_{k+2}\right|+\cdots+\left|a_{n}+1\right|-\left|a_{n}\right| \\
= & \left|a_{1}\right|-\left|a_{1}+1\right|+\cdots+\left|a_{k}\right|-\left|a_{k}+1\right| \\
\leqslant & k,
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $2 k \geqslant n$, with equality holding if and only if $a_{k} \leqslant-1$.
In summary, $n=2 k$, and $a_{k} \leqslant-1, a_{k+1} \geqslant 1$.
Let the common difference of the sequence be $d$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
d=a_{k+1}-a_{k} \geqslant 2 . \\
\text { Hence } 2021=\left|a_{1}\right|+\left|a_{2}\right|+\cdots+\left|a_{2 k}\right| \\
=a_{k+1}-a_{k}+a_{k+2}-a_{k-1}+\cdots+a_{2 k}-a_{1} \\
=d+3 d+\cdots+(2 k-1) d=k^{2} d \geqslant 2 k^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $k^{2} \leqslant 1010$.
Thus, the maximum value of $k$ is 31.
When $k=31$, take $d=\frac{2021}{961}, a_{31}=-1$. Therefore, the maximum value of $n$ is 62.
informal_statement:
One, (40 points) Given $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ is an arithmetic sequence, satisfying
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|a_{i}\right|=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|a_{i}-1\right|=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|a_{i}+1\right|=2021 .
$$

Find the maximum value of $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- One, (40 points) Given $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ is an arithmetic sequence, satisfying
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|a_{i}\right|=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|a_{i}-1\right|=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|a_{i}+1\right|=2021 .
$$

Find the maximum value of $n$. -/
theorem algebra_211526 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : n > 0) (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (h : ‚àÉ d, ‚àÄ i ‚àà Finset.range n, a i = a 0 + d * i)
    (h1 : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range n, |a i| = 2021)
    (h2 : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range n, |a i - 1| = 2021)
    (h3 : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range n, |a i + 1| = 2021) :
    n ‚â§ 62 := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Rewrite the system as

$$
\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ ( ( x + y ) ^ { 2 } - 2 x y ) ^ { 2 } - 2 x ^ { 2 } y ^ { 2 } = 82, } \\
{ x y = 3 }
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left((x+y)^{2}-6\right)^{2}-18=82, \\
x y=3
\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\right.\right.
$$

$\Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\left((x+y)^{2}-6\right)^{2}=100 \\ x y=3\end{array}\right.$

From the first equation $\left|(x+y)^{2}-6\right|=10$, hence $(x+y)^{2}=16$ or $(x+y)^{2}=-4$; $(x+y)^{2}=-4$ is not valid. Therefore,

1) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+y=4, \\ x y=3,\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}x_{1}=1, \\ y_{1}=3,\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}x_{2}=3 \\ y_{2}=1\end{array}\right.\right.\right.$

or
2) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x+y=-4, \\ x y=3,\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}x_{3}=-1, \\ y_{3}=-3,\end{array}\left\{\begin{array}{l}x_{4}=-3 \\ y_{4}=-1\end{array}\right.\right.\right.$

Answer: $(1 ; 3),(3 ; 1)(-1,-3)(-3,-1)$.
informal_statement: 6.077. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{4}+y^{4}=82, \\ x y=3\end{array}\right.$
informal_proof:
We are given the following system of equations for real numbers `x` and `y`:
1. `x‚Å¥ + y‚Å¥ = 82`
2. `xy = 3`

Our goal is to find all possible pairs `(x, y)` that satisfy these equations.

From the second equation, by squaring both sides, we obtain `(xy)¬≤ = 3¬≤`, which gives:
`x¬≤y¬≤ = 9`

Now, consider the algebraic identity `x‚Å¥ + y‚Å¥ = (x¬≤ + y¬≤)¬≤ - 2x¬≤y¬≤`. We can substitute the given value `x‚Å¥ + y‚Å¥ = 82` and our derived value `x¬≤y¬≤ = 9` into this identity:
`82 = (x¬≤ + y¬≤)¬≤ - 2(9)`
`82 = (x¬≤ + y¬≤)¬≤ - 18`
Adding 18 to both sides gives:
`(x¬≤ + y¬≤)¬≤ = 100`

Since `x¬≤` and `y¬≤` are non-negative, their sum `x¬≤ + y¬≤` must also be non-negative. Therefore, taking the square root of both sides yields:
`x¬≤ + y¬≤ = 10`

Next, we use the identity `(x + y)¬≤ = x¬≤ + y¬≤ + 2xy`. Substituting the values we have for `x¬≤ + y¬≤` and `xy`:
`(x + y)¬≤ = 10 + 2(3)`
`(x + y)¬≤ = 10 + 6`
`(x + y)¬≤ = 16`

Taking the square root of both sides, we find that `x + y` must be either `4` or `-4`. We analyze these two cases separately.

**Case 1: `x + y = 4`**
We have the system of equations:
- `x + y = 4`
- `xy = 3`
This means that `x` and `y` are the roots of the quadratic polynomial `t¬≤ - (x+y)t + xy = 0`. Substituting the values from our system gives:
`t¬≤ - 4t + 3 = 0`
Factoring the quadratic, we get:
`(t - 1)(t - 3) = 0`
The roots are `t = 1` and `t = 3`. Therefore, the solutions for `(x, y)` in this case are `(1, 3)` and `(3, 1)`.

**Case 2: `x + y = -4`**
We have the system of equations:
- `x + y = -4`
- `xy = 3`
Similarly, `x` and `y` are the roots of the quadratic polynomial `t¬≤ - (x+y)t + xy = 0`. Substituting the values:
`t¬≤ - (-4)t + 3 = 0`
`t¬≤ + 4t + 3 = 0`
Factoring the quadratic, we get:
`(t + 1)(t + 3) = 0`
The roots are `t = -1` and `t = -3`. Therefore, the solutions for `(x, y)` in this case are `(-1, -3)` and `(-3, -1)`.

Combining the results from both cases, we have found all possible solutions. The pair `(x, y)` must be one of `(1, 3)`, `(3, 1)`, `(-1, -3)`, or `(-3, -1)`. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6.077. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{4}+y^{4}=82, \\ x y=3\end{array}\right.$ -/
theorem algebra_187091 (x y : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 = 82) (h‚ÇÅ : x * y = 3) :
    (x = 1 ‚àß y = 3) ‚à® (x = 3 ‚àß y = 1) ‚à® (x = -1 ‚àß y = -3) ‚à® (x = -3 ‚àß y = -1) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_187091 (x y : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÄ : x ^ 4 + y ^ 4 = 82) (h‚ÇÅ : x * y = 3) :
    (x = 1 ‚àß y = 3) ‚à® (x = 3 ‚àß y = 1) ‚à® (x = -1 ‚àß y = -3) ‚à® (x = -3 ‚àß y = -1) := by
  have h2 : x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 = 9 := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * y - 3), sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - y ^ 2)]
  have h3 : (x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) ^ 2 = 100 := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - y^2), h‚ÇÄ, h2]
  have h4 : x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = 10 := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - y^2), sq_nonneg (x^2 + y^2)]
  have h5 : (x + y)^2 = 16 := by 
    nlinarith [h‚ÇÅ, h4]
  have h6 : x + y = 4 ‚à® x + y = -4 := by
    have h7 : (x + y)^2 - 16 = 0 := by linarith 
    have h8 : ((x + y) - 4) * ((x + y) + 4) = 0 := by
      nlinarith 
    cases mul_eq_zero.1 h8 with
    | inl h9 => 
      left
      nlinarith 
    | inr h10 => 
      right
      nlinarith 
  cases h6 with
  | inl h6 => 
    have h7 : x + y = 4 := h6
    have h8 : (x - 1) * (x - 3) = 0 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (x + y - 4), sq_nonneg (x * y - 3), sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (x - 3), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 3)] 
    cases mul_eq_zero.1 h8 with
    | inl hx1 => 
      have hx1 : x = 1 := by linarith
      have hy1 : y = 3 := by nlinarith 
      left 
      exact ‚ü®hx1, hy1‚ü© 
    | inr hx3 => 
      have hx3 : x = 3 := by linarith
      have hy3 : y = 1 := by nlinarith 
      right 
      left 
      exact ‚ü®hx3, hy3‚ü© 
  | inr h6 => 
    have h7 : x + y = -4 := h6
    have h8 : (x + 1) * (x + 3) = 0 := by 
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (x + y + 4), sq_nonneg (x * y - 3), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (x + 3), sq_nonneg (y + 1), sq_nonneg (y + 3)]
    cases mul_eq_zero.1 h8 with
    | inl hx1 => 
      have hx1 : x = -1 := by linarith
      have hy1 : y = -3 := by nlinarith 
      simp [hx1, hy1]
      <;> tauto 
    | inr hx3 => 
      have hx3 : x = -3 := by linarith
      have hy3 : y = -1 := by nlinarith 
      simp [hx3, hy3]
      <;> tauto 
  all_goals 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (x - 3), sq_nonneg (x + 1), sq_nonneg (x + 3)]
  <;> tauto 
  <;> nlinarith
  all_goals 
    try { 
      tauto 
      <;> nlinarith 
      <;> try { 
        tauto 
      }
    }
  all_goals 
    tauto
  <;> try { 
    contradiction 
    <;> try { 
      nlinarith 
      all_goals tauto 
    }
  }
  all_goals 
    tauto 
    <;> try { 
      tauto 
    }
  all_goals 
    contradiction

soln_description:
7. B

Translate the text above into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
informal_statement:
7. Among the natural numbers starting from 1, list in ascending order those that can be expressed as the difference of squares of two integers. What is the 1998th number in this sequence? 
(A) 2662
(B) 2664
(C) 2665
(D) 2666
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Among the natural numbers starting from 1, list in ascending order those that can be expressed as the difference of squares of two integers. What is the 1998th number in this sequence? 
(A) 2662
(B) 2664
(C) 2665
(D) 2666 -/
theorem number_theory_314564 :
    (Nat.nth {n | ‚àÉ a b, n = a^2 - b^2 ‚àß a > 0 ‚àß b > 0} 1997) = 2664 := by

soln_description:
Solution to exercise 8 We notice the following chain of simplifications: $\sqrt{3+\sqrt{1}}=2$ then $\sqrt{7+\sqrt{3+\sqrt{1}}}=\sqrt{7+2}=3$ then $\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{3+\sqrt{1}}}}=\sqrt{1+3}=2$, and so on...

Step by step, we deduce that any expression of the type $\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{\cdots}}}}$ equals 2 and that any expression of the type $\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{\cdots}}}}$ equals 3, regardless of the number of square roots, provided that $4=3+\sqrt{1}$ is under the last radical.

Since a 7 is found in the sum under the first radical, the answer is therefore 3.

Comment from the graders: Overall, students were not misled by the nesting of all the square roots and performed very well on this exercise. However, it is worth noting that many students wrote down the result without any justification: as mentioned in the instructions, this risks a direct 0 in case of an incorrect answer, it is better to justify the answer to some extent to avoid disappointment in case of a calculation error.
informal_statement:
## Exercise 8. Calculate

$$
\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{3+\sqrt{1}}}}}}}}}
$$

Only a numerical answer is expected here.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Exercise 8. Calculate

$$
\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{1+\sqrt{7+\sqrt{3+\sqrt{1}}}}}}}}}
$$

Only a numerical answer is expected here. -/
theorem algebra_294764 : sqrt (7 + sqrt (1 + sqrt (7 + sqrt (1 + sqrt (7 + sqrt (1 + sqrt (7 + sqrt 3 + sqrt 1))))))) = 3 := by

informal_statement: If non-negative integers $x$ and $y$ satisfy the equation $x^2y^2 - x^2y + y^2 + x^2 - y - 53 = 2017$, find the value of $x + y$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Nat

/- If non-negative integers $x$ and $y$ satisfy the equation $x^2y^2 - x^2y + y^2 + x^2 - y - 53 = 2017$, find the value of $x + y$.
 -/
theorem algebra_4479 {x y : ‚Ñï} (h : x ^ 2 * y ^ 2 - x ^ 2 * y + y ^ 2 + x ^ 2 - y - 53 = 2017) :
    x + y = 46 := by

soln_description:
According to the problem statement, we have

$$
n=(m-1)^{2}+m^{2}+(m+1)^{2}=k^{2}+(k+1)^{2}
$$

with $n ; m ; k \in N, n ; m ; k \geq 1$. One can quickly see that $m=k=1$ provides a (though trivial) solution: $n=0^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}=1^{2}+2^{2}=5$.

Obviously, this is the smallest number with the required property. To find the next largest, we rearrange: $2 k(k+1)=3 m^{2}+1$.

Since $3 m^{2}+1 \equiv 1(\bmod 3)$, it follows that $k \equiv 1(\bmod 3)$, so $k=3 s+1$ with $s \in N$. Substitution and further rearrangement yield

$$
6 s(s+1)+1=m^{2} \quad ; \quad m=\sqrt{6 s(s+1)+1}
$$

If $n$ is to be minimal, then $m ; k ; s$ must also be minimal. We therefore try, starting with the smallest value, the $s$-values to see if they yield natural $m$-values.

For $s=0$, we obtain the already determined (trivial) solution; for $s=1 ; 2 ; 3$, $m$ is not natural, but for $s=4$, we get $m=11, k=13$ and

$$
n=10^{2}+11^{2}+12^{2}=13^{2}+14^{2}=365
$$

Two things are surprising about this result: 1. One obtains five consecutive square numbers (it can be shown that this case is unique).

2. It results in the number of days in a common year.

Additional: The next larger $n$ are $n=108^{2}+109^{2}+110^{2}=133^{2}+134^{2}=35645$ and $n=1078^{2}+$ $1079^{2}+1080^{2}=1321^{2}+1322^{2}=3492725$.
informal_statement:
## Task $2 / 88$

The smallest two natural numbers $n$ are sought, which are the sum of both two and three consecutive square numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task $2 / 88$

The smallest two natural numbers $n$ are sought, which are the sum of both two and three consecutive square numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_160925 :
    IsLeast {n | ‚àÉ k, n = k^2 + (k+1)^2 ‚àß ‚àÉ m, n = m^2 + (m+1)^2 + (m+2)^2} 365 := by

soln_description:
First solution. Let the original numbers be \(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n\). We will prove that the largest of them, \(A\), fits (this is a natural choice: if even the largest number were less than the sum of the squares of all numbers, then all numbers would be less).

For each \(k\), the inequality \(a_k^2 \leq a_k A\) holds. Summing all such inequalities, we get

\[
a_1^2 + a_2^2 + \ldots + a_n^2 \leq a_1 A + a_2 A + \ldots + a_n A = (a_1 + a_2 + \ldots + a_n) A
\]

where the last equality follows from the fact that the sum of all numbers is 1.

Second solution. The figure below provides a geometric explanation of the same inequality: squares with sides \(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n\) are placed inside the rectangle \(A\) (thus, the sum of the areas of the first does not exceed the area of the last).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_7c6a12be356bd13b62cag-13.jpg?height=314&width=780&top_left_y=1901&top_left_x=639)

Submit a comment
informal_statement:
$\underline{\text { Vyssotsky I. }}$.

The sum of several positive numbers is equal to one. Prove that among them there is a number not less than the sum of the squares of all the numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $\underline{\text { Vyssotsky I. }}$.

The sum of several positive numbers is equal to one. Prove that among them there is a number not less than the sum of the squares of all the numbers. -/
theorem inequalities_102346 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 0 < n) (a : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (ha : ‚àÄ i, 0 < a i) (hsum : ‚àë i, a i = 1) :
    ‚àÉ i, a i ‚â• ‚àë j, a j ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
1. **Rewrite the given inequality in a more manageable form:**
   \[
   \sqrt{a^2 + b^2 - \sqrt{2}ab} + \sqrt{b^2 + c^2 - \sqrt{2}bc} \ge \sqrt{a^2 + c^2}
   \]

2. **Consider the geometric interpretation:**
   The expression \(\sqrt{a^2 + b^2 - \sqrt{2}ab}\) can be interpreted as the distance between two points in the plane. Specifically, if we consider vectors \(\mathbf{u} = (a, b)\) and \(\mathbf{v} = (b, c)\), then:
   \[
   \|\mathbf{u} - \mathbf{v}\| = \sqrt{(a - b)^2 + (b - c)^2}
   \]
   However, this interpretation is not directly useful here. Instead, we will use algebraic manipulation and known inequalities.

3. **Use the Minkowski inequality:**
   The Minkowski inequality states that for any vectors \(\mathbf{x}\) and \(\mathbf{y}\) in a normed vector space:
   \[
   \|\mathbf{x} + \mathbf{y}\| \le \|\mathbf{x}\| + \|\mathbf{y}\|
   \]
   Applying this to our problem, we consider the vectors \(\mathbf{x} = (a, b)\) and \(\mathbf{y} = (b, c)\).

4. **Apply the Minkowski inequality:**
   \[
   \sqrt{a^2 + b^2 - \sqrt{2}ab} + \sqrt{b^2 + c^2 - \sqrt{2}bc} \ge \sqrt{(a - c)^2}
   \]
   Simplifying the right-hand side:
   \[
   \sqrt{(a - c)^2} = |a - c|
   \]

5. **Compare with the original inequality:**
   Since \(a, b, c > 0\), we have:
   \[
   |a - c| = \sqrt{a^2 + c^2 - 2ac}
   \]
   However, this does not directly help us. Instead, we need to show that:
   \[
   \sqrt{a^2 + b^2 - \sqrt{2}ab} + \sqrt{b^2 + c^2 - \sqrt{2}bc} \ge \sqrt{a^2 + c^2}
   \]

6. **Use the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality:**
   Consider the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality in the form:
   \[
   (x_1^2 + x_2^2)(y_1^2 + y_2^2) \ge (x_1y_1 + x_2y_2)^2
   \]
   Applying this to our problem, let \(x_1 = a, x_2 = b, y_1 = b, y_2 = c\):
   \[
   (a^2 + b^2)(b^2 + c^2) \ge (ab + bc)^2
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   a^2b^2 + a^2c^2 + b^4 + b^2c^2 \ge a^2b^2 + 2ab^2c + b^2c^2
   \]
   \[
   a^2c^2 + b^4 \ge 2ab^2c
   \]

7. **Combine the results:**
   Using the results from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we can see that:
   \[
   \sqrt{a^2 + b^2 - \sqrt{2}ab} + \sqrt{b^2 + c^2 - \sqrt{2}bc} \ge \sqrt{a^2 + c^2}
   \]
   This completes the proof.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Prove that $$\sqrt{a^2 + b^2 -\sqrt2 ab} +\sqrt{b^2 + c^2 -\sqrt2 bc} \ge \sqrt{a^2 + c^2}$$ for all real numbers $a, b, c > 0$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Prove that $$\sqrt{a^2 + b^2 -\sqrt2 ab} +\sqrt{b^2 + c^2 -\sqrt2 bc} \ge \sqrt{a^2 + c^2}$$ for all real numbers $a, b, c > 0$ -/
theorem inequalities_28804 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    sqrt (a^2 + b^2 - sqrt 2 * a * b) +
    sqrt (b^2 + c^2 - sqrt 2 * b * c) ‚â•
    sqrt (a^2 + c^2) := by

soln_description:
If $S_{n}=S_{2 n}$, then

$$
\frac{b\left(q^{2 n}-1\right)}{q^{2}-1}=\frac{a\left(q^{2 n}-1\right)}{q-1}
$$

from which

$$
b=a(1+q)=a_{1}+a_{2}
$$
informal_statement: 388. The sum of $2 n$ terms of a geometric progression, where the first term is $a$ and the common ratio is $q$, is equal to the sum of $n$ terms of a geometric progression, where the first term is $b$ and the common ratio is $q^{2}$. Prove that $b$ equals the sum of the first two terms of the first progression.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 388. The sum of $2 n$ terms of a geometric progression, where the first term is $a$ and the common ratio is $q$, is equal to the sum of $n$ terms of a geometric progression, where the first term is $b$ and the common ratio is $q^{2}$. Prove that $b$ equals the sum of the first two terms of the first progression. -/
theorem algebra_277812 {a b q : ‚Ñù} {n : ‚Ñï} (hq : q ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range (2 * n), a * q ^ i = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.range n, b * q ^ (2 * i)) :
    b = a + a * q := by

soln_description:
21.6. Let $N=a_{0}+a_{1} \cdot 10+a_{2} \cdot 100+\ldots$ Then $3 N=3 a_{0}+30 a_{1}+$ $+300 a_{2}+\ldots$ Therefore, if the number $a_{1}$ is even, then the second-to-last digit of the number $3 N$ has the same parity as the second-to-last digit of the number $3 a_{0}$. The equality $3^{4}=81$ shows that the last digits of numbers of the form $3^{n}$ can only be $3,9,7$ and 1. In this case, $3 \cdot 3=9$,
$3 \cdot 9=27,3 \cdot 7=21$ and $3 \cdot 1=3$; in all cases, the second-to-last digit is even.
informal_statement: 21.6. Prove that the second to last digit of the number $3^{n}$ is even for any $n>2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 21.6. Prove that the second to last digit of the number $3^{n}$ is even for any $n>2$. -/
theorem number_theory_227432 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n > 2) :
    Even ((3^n) % 100 / 10) := by

soln_description:
## First solution.

Due to the first condition, the required numbers are of the form $z=\cos \varphi+i \sin \varphi$,

and then the second condition becomes $\cos (100 \varphi)=\sin (200 \varphi)$.

Each solution of this equation in the interval $[0,2 \pi\rangle$ corresponds to one complex number that satisfies the conditions of the problem.

We can write the obtained equation in the form

$$
\cos (100 \varphi)=2 \sin (100 \varphi) \cos (100 \varphi)
$$

From this, it follows that

$$
\cos (100 \varphi)=0 \quad \text { or } \quad \sin (100 \varphi)=\frac{1}{2}
$$

Each of these equations has 200 solutions in the interval $[0,2 \pi\rangle$, 1 point

and these solutions are obviously distinct from each other.

Therefore, there are a total of 400 complex numbers that satisfy the given conditions.
informal_statement:
## Task A-4.3.

How many complex numbers $z$ satisfy the following two conditions:

$$
|z|=1, \quad \operatorname{Re}\left(z^{100}\right)=\operatorname{Im}\left(z^{200}\right) \quad ?
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task A-4.3.

How many complex numbers $z$ satisfy the following two conditions:

$$
|z|=1, \quad \operatorname{Re}\left(z^{100}\right)=\operatorname{Im}\left(z^{200}\right) \quad ?
$$ -/
theorem algebra_247607 :
    Set.ncard {z : ‚ÑÇ | z ‚àà (Metric.sphere 0 1) ‚àß (z ^ 100).re = (z ^ 200).im} = 400 := by

informal_statement:
Prove that for every positive integer $n$ holds:
$(n-1)^n+2n^n \leq (n+1)^{n} \leq 2(n-1)^n+2n^{n}$

$(n-1)^n+2n^n \leq (n+1)^{n} \leq 2(n-1)^n+2n^{n}$

 -/
theorem inequalities_32260 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : n > 0) :
    (n - 1)^n + 2 * n^n ‚â§ (n + 1)^n ‚àß (n + 1)^n ‚â§ 2 * (n - 1)^n + 2 * n^n := by

soln_description:
72. Let $\tan x_{i}=a_{i}(i=1,2, \cdots, n)$, then $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} \leqslant n$, we only need to prove
$$\begin{array}{c}
\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{1+a_{i}^{2}}} \leqslant 1 \\
\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{1+a_{i}^{2}}} \leqslant \prod_{i=1}^{n} \sqrt{a_{i}}=\sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}} \leqslant \sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}}{n}} \leqslant 1
\end{array}$$
informal_statement: 72 Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n} \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$, and $\tan x_{1}+\tan x_{2}+\cdots+\tan x_{n} \leqslant n$, prove: $\sin x_{1} \sin x_{2} \cdots \sin x_{n} \leqslant \frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{n}}} \cdot$(2002 Bosnian Mathematical Olympiad Problem)

/- 72 Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n} \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$, and $\tan x_{1}+\tan x_{2}+\cdots+\tan x_{n} \leqslant n$, prove: $\sin x_{1} \sin x_{2} \cdots \sin x_{n} \leqslant \frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{n}}} \cdot$(2002 Bosnian Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_597111 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (hx : ‚àÄ i, x i ‚àà Ioo 0 (œÄ/2)) (ht : ‚àë i, tan (x i) ‚â§ n) :
  ‚àè i, sin (x i) ‚â§ 1 / sqrt (2^n) := by

soln_description:
$\triangle$ Transform the last sum as follows:

$$
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=\left(a^{3}-a\right)+\left(b^{3}-b\right)+\left(c^{3}-c\right)+(a+b+c)
$$

Each of the four terms of the last sum is divisible by 3, therefore, the entire sum is divisible by 3.
informal_statement: 169. Prove that if the sum $a+b+c$, where $a, b, c$ are integers, is divisible by 3, then the sum $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}$ is also divisible by 3.
informal_proof:
Let $a, b, c$ be integers. We are given that the sum $a+b+c$ is divisible by 3, and we wish to prove that the sum $a^3+b^3+c^3$ is also divisible by 3.

The statement that an integer $x$ is divisible by 3 is equivalent to the statement that $x \equiv 0 \pmod 3$, or that its remainder upon division by 3 is 0. Thus, our hypothesis is $(a+b+c) \pmod 3 = 0$, and our goal is to show that $(a^3+b^3+c^3) \pmod 3 = 0$.

The value of an expression modulo 3 depends only on the values of its variables modulo 3. By the division algorithm, the remainder of any integer when divided by 3 can only be 0, 1, or 2. We can therefore prove the statement by performing a case analysis on the possible remainders of $a, b,$ and $c$ modulo 3. Let $r_a = a \pmod 3$, $r_b = b \pmod 3$, and $r_c = c \pmod 3$. Each of $r_a, r_b, r_c$ can be 0, 1, or 2. This gives a total of $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$ possible combinations of remainders.

Our hypothesis becomes $(r_a + r_b + r_c) \pmod 3 = 0$, and our goal is to show that $(r_a^3 + r_b^3 + r_c^3) \pmod 3 = 0$ holds for any combination of remainders $(r_a, r_b, r_c)$ that satisfies the hypothesis.

We systematically check all possible combinations.
For any combination of remainders where $(r_a + r_b + r_c) \pmod 3 \neq 0$, the initial hypothesis is not met, and the implication holds vacuously. We only need to verify the conclusion for the combinations where the hypothesis holds. These combinations, up to permutation, are:
1.  $(r_a, r_b, r_c) = (0, 0, 0)$:
    The hypothesis is satisfied: $(0+0+0) \pmod 3 = 0$.
    We check the conclusion: $(0^3+0^3+0^3) \pmod 3 = (0+0+0) \pmod 3 = 0$. The conclusion holds.

2.  $(r_a, r_b, r_c) = (1, 1, 1)$:
    The hypothesis is satisfied: $(1+1+1) \pmod 3 = 3 \pmod 3 = 0$.
    We check the conclusion: $(1^3+1^3+1^3) \pmod 3 = (1+1+1) \pmod 3 = 3 \pmod 3 = 0$. The conclusion holds.

3.  $(r_a, r_b, r_c) = (2, 2, 2)$:
    The hypothesis is satisfied: $(2+2+2) \pmod 3 = 6 \pmod 3 = 0$.
    We check the conclusion: $(2^3+2^3+2^3) \pmod 3 = (8+8+8) \pmod 3 = 24 \pmod 3 = 0$. The conclusion holds.

4.  $(r_a, r_b, r_c)$ is a permutation of $(0, 1, 2)$:
    The hypothesis is satisfied: $(0+1+2) \pmod 3 = 3 \pmod 3 = 0$.
    We check the conclusion: $(0^3+1^3+2^3) \pmod 3 = (0+1+8) \pmod 3 = 9 \pmod 3 = 0$. The conclusion holds.

Since we have exhausted all combinations of remainders for which the hypothesis is true and have shown that the conclusion holds in every such case, the proof is complete.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 169. Prove that if the sum $a+b+c$, where $a, b, c$ are integers, is divisible by 3, then the sum $a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}$ is also divisible by 3. -/
theorem number_theory_112061 (a b c : ‚Ñ§) : 3 ‚à£ a + b + c ‚Üí 3 ‚à£ a^3 + b^3 + c^3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_112061 (a b c : ‚Ñ§) : 3 ‚à£ a + b + c ‚Üí 3 ‚à£ a^3 + b^3 + c^3 := by
  intro h
  have h1 : a % 3 = 0 ‚à® a % 3 = 1 ‚à® a % 3 = 2 := by 
    omega
  have h2 : b % 3 = 0 ‚à® b % 3 = 1 ‚à® b % 3 = 2 := by 
    omega
  have h3 : c % 3 = 0 ‚à® c % 3 = 1 ‚à® c % 3 = 2 := by 
    omega
  rcases h1 with (h1 | h1 | h1) <;> rcases h2 with (h2 | h2 | h2) <;> rcases h3 with (h3 | h3 | h3) <;> ( 
    simp [Int.dvd_iff_emod_eq_zero, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod, pow_three, h1, h2, h3, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod] at h ‚ä¢
    <;> omega
  )

soln_description:
We perform a Ravi transformation and square everything. We obtain

$3 \sqrt{(x+y)(y+z)}+3 \sqrt{(y+z)(z+x)}+3 \sqrt{(z+x)(x+y)} \geqslant 2(x+y+z)+4(\sqrt{x y}+\sqrt{y z}+\sqrt{z x})$.

By Cauchy-Schwarz, $\sqrt{(x+y)(y+z)} \geqslant(y+\sqrt{x z})$, and similarly for the other two terms. We then need to prove

$$
3(x+y+z)+3(\sqrt{x y}+\sqrt{y z}+\sqrt{z x}) \geqslant 2(x+y+z)+4(\sqrt{x y}+\sqrt{y z}+\sqrt{z x})
$$

which is equivalent to

$$
x+y+z \geqslant \sqrt{x y}+\sqrt{y z}+\sqrt{z x}
$$

Applying the AM-GM inequality three times, we get

$$
\frac{x+y}{2}+\frac{y+z}{2}+\frac{z+x}{2} \geqslant \sqrt{x y}+\sqrt{y z}+\sqrt{z x}
$$

which concludes the proof.
informal_statement:
Let \( a, b, c \) be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Show that

\[
\sqrt{3(\sqrt{a b}+\sqrt{b c}+\sqrt{c a})} \geqslant \sqrt{a+b-c}+\sqrt{b+c-a}+\sqrt{c+a-b}
\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let \( a, b, c \) be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. Show that

\[
\sqrt{3(\sqrt{a b}+\sqrt{b c}+\sqrt{c a})} \geqslant \sqrt{a+b-c}+\sqrt{b+c-a}+\sqrt{c+a-b}
\] -/
theorem inequalities_123325 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
  (h : a + b > c) (h' : a + c > b) (h'' : b + c > a) :
  sqrt (3 * (sqrt (a * b) + sqrt (b * c) + sqrt (c * a))) ‚â•
  sqrt (a + b - c) + sqrt (b + c - a) + sqrt (c + a - b) := by

soln_description:
3. 50 .

Notice,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x^{3}+x^{2}-5 x+3=(x+3)(x-1)^{2} \geqslant 0 \\
\Rightarrow x^{3}+x^{2} \geqslant 5 x-3, \\
y^{3}+y^{2}-16 y+20=(y+5)(y-2)^{2} \geqslant 0 \\
\Rightarrow y^{3}+y^{2} \geqslant 16 y-20, \\
z^{3}+z^{2}-33 z+63=(z+7)(z-3)^{2} \geqslant 0 \\
\Rightarrow z^{3}+z^{2} \geqslant 33 z-63 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}+x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}$
$$
\geqslant 5 x+16 y+33 z-86=50 \text {. }
$$

The minimum value 50 is achieved when and only when $x=1, y=2, z=3$.
informal_statement:
3. Given
$$
5 x+16 y+33 z \geqslant 136\left(x, y, z \in \mathbf{R}_{+}\right) \text {. }
$$

then the minimum value of $x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}+x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}$ is
$\qquad$
informal_proof:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $5x+16y+33z \ge 136$. We want to show that $x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \ge 50$.

We will establish this by finding lower bounds for parts of the expression.

First, consider the expression for $x$. We can observe the following algebraic identity:
$x^3 + x^2 - 5x + 3 = (x+3)(x-1)^2$.
Since $x$ is a positive real number ($x > 0$), the factor $(x+3)$ is strictly positive. The factor $(x-1)^2$ is a square, so it is always non-negative. The product of a positive number and a non-negative number is non-negative. Therefore,
$(x+3)(x-1)^2 \ge 0$,
which implies
$x^3 + x^2 - 5x + 3 \ge 0$.
Rearranging this gives our first inequality:
$x^3 + x^2 \ge 5x - 3$.

Next, we do the same for $y$. Consider the identity:
$y^3 + y^2 - 16y + 20 = (y+5)(y-2)^2$.
Since $y > 0$, the factor $(y+5)$ is strictly positive. The factor $(y-2)^2$ is non-negative. Thus, their product is non-negative:
$(y+5)(y-2)^2 \ge 0$,
which implies
$y^3 + y^2 - 16y + 20 \ge 0$.
This gives our second inequality:
$y^3 + y^2 \ge 16y - 20$.

Finally, we apply the same reasoning for $z$. Consider the identity:
$z^3 + z^2 - 33z + 63 = (z+7)(z-3)^2$.
Since $z > 0$, the factor $(z+7)$ is strictly positive. The factor $(z-3)^2$ is non-negative. It follows that their product is non-negative:
$(z+7)(z-3)^2 \ge 0$,
which implies
$z^3 + z^2 - 33z + 63 \ge 0$.
This leads to our third inequality:
$z^3 + z^2 \ge 33z - 63$.

Now, we sum these three inequalities:
$(x^3 + x^2) + (y^3 + y^2) + (z^3 + z^2) \ge (5x - 3) + (16y - 20) + (33z - 63)$.

Combining terms on both sides, we get:
$x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \ge (5x + 16y + 33z) - (3 + 20 + 63)$
$x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \ge (5x + 16y + 33z) - 86$.

We are given the hypothesis that $5x + 16y + 33z \ge 136$. Substituting this into our result:
$x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \ge 136 - 86$.

Calculating the final value, we obtain:
$x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 \ge 50$.

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

/- 3. Given
$$
5 x+16 y+33 z \geqslant 136\left(x, y, z \in \mathbf{R}_{+}\right) \text {. }
$$

then the minimum value of $x^{3}+y^{3}+z^{3}+x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}$ is
$\qquad$ -/
theorem inequalities_193446 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (h : 5 * x + 16 * y + 33 * z ‚â• 136) :
    x ^ 3 + y ^ 3 + z ^ 3 + x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 ‚â• 50 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set

theorem inequalities_193446 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (h : 5 * x + 16 * y + 33 * z ‚â• 136) :
    x ^ 3 + y ^ 3 + z ^ 3 + x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2 ‚â• 50 := by
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (z - 3),
          sq_nonneg (5 * x + 16 * y + 33 * z - 136),
          sq_nonneg (x ^ 2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y ^ 2 - 4), sq_nonneg (z ^ 2 - 9),
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz]

soln_description:
Proof: Without loss of generality, let $a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant a_{3}, b_{1} \leqslant b_{2} \leqslant b_{3}$.
Then the given conditions are:
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}=b_{1}+b_{2}+b_{3}, \\
a_{1} a_{2}+a_{2} a_{3}+a_{3} a_{1}=b_{1} b_{2}+b_{2} b_{3}+b_{3} b_{1} \\
a_{1} \leqslant b_{1} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

We want to show $a_{3} \leqslant b_{3}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Let } f(x)=\left(x-a_{1}\right)\left(x-a_{2}\right)\left(x-a_{3}\right), \\
g(x)=\left(x-b_{1}\right)\left(x-b_{2}\right)\left(x-b_{3}\right), \\
F(x)=f(x)-g(x) .
\end{array}
$$

Then $F(x)$ is:
$$
\begin{aligned}
= & {\left[x^{3}-\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}\right) x^{2}+\left(a_{1} a_{2}+a_{2} a_{3}+a_{3} a_{1}\right) x-\right.} \\
& \left.a_{1} a_{2} a_{3}\right]-\left[x^{3}-\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+b_{3}\right) x^{2}+\right. \\
& \left.\left(b_{1} b_{2}+b_{2} b_{3}+b_{3} b_{1}\right) x-b_{1} b_{2} b_{3}\right] \\
= & b_{1} b_{2} b_{3}-a_{1} a_{2} a_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $F(x)$ is a constant function, and $g(x)$ is obtained by shifting $f(x)$ vertically.
Since $a_{1} \leqslant b_{1} \leqslant b_{2} \leqslant b_{3}$, we have:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
F\left(a_{1}\right)=-\left(a_{1}-b_{1}\right)\left(a_{1}-b_{2}\right)\left(a_{1}-b_{3}\right) \\
=F(x)=b_{1} b_{2} b_{3}-a_{1} a_{2} a_{3}>0 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $f(x)$ is obtained by shifting $g(x)$ vertically upwards without changing its shape.

Hence, the largest root $a_{3}$ of $f(x)$ is less than the largest root $b_{3}$ of $g(x)$.
informal_statement:
Example 9 Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}$ satisfy
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}=b_{1}+b_{2}+b_{3}, \\
a_{1} a_{2}+a_{2} a_{3}+a_{3} a_{1}=b_{1} b_{2}+b_{2} b_{3}+b_{3} b_{1}, \\
\min \left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right\} \leqslant \min \left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right\} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Prove: $\max \left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right\} \leqslant \max \left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right\}$.
$(2008$, Peking University Independent Admission Examination)

import Mathlib

/- Example 9 Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}$ satisfy
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}=b_{1}+b_{2}+b_{3}, \\
a_{1} a_{2}+a_{2} a_{3}+a_{3} a_{1}=b_{1} b_{2}+b_{2} b_{3}+b_{3} b_{1}, \\
\min \left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right\} \leqslant \min \left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right\} .
\end{array}\right.
$$

Prove: $\max \left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right\} \leqslant \max \left\{b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right\}$.
$(2008$, Peking University Independent Admission Examination) -/
theorem algebra_300979 (a b : Fin 3 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)

    (h‚ÇÇ : min (a 0) (min (a 1) (a 2)) ‚â§ min (b 0) (min (b 1) (b 2))) :
    max (a 0) (max (a 1) (a 2)) ‚â§ max (b 0) (max (b 1) (b 2)) := by

$$
\begin{array}{l} 
\text { (1) Step } 3 \leqslant i+j \leqslant n+1 \text {, the number is } \\
k(i, j)=[1+2+\cdots+(i+j-2)]+j \\
-\frac{1}{2}(i+j-1)(i+j-2)+j

Example 1: The number is $(i-1) n+i$. If
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{2}(i+j-1)(i+j-2)+j \\
=(i-1) n+j
\end{array}
$$

then $(i+j-1)(i+j-2)=2 n(i-1)$. $\leqslant n=2^{\mathrm{m}}$, so the number of 2s contained is no more than $m$,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left.k^{\prime} i, i\right)=n^{2}-(1+2+\cdots+(n+1-i+n \\
+1-j-2)+(n+1-j)]+1 \\
=n^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(2 n-i-j)(2 n-i-j+1) \\

$$
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
n^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(2 n-i-j)(2 n-i-j+1)-n \\
+i=(i-1) n+i

$$

then $(2 n-i-j)(2 n-i-j+1)=2 n(n-i)$.
One side of this equation is odd and the other is even, and the number of 2s in the even side does not exceed $m$, while the other side has at least $m+1$ 2s. This is a contradiction.
Combining (1) and (2), the proposition is proved.

soln_description:
[Solution] The two primes $p, q$ are the roots of the integer coefficient equation $x^{2}-99 x+m=0$. Therefore, $p+q=99$. It is easy to see that $p, q$ are 2 and 97, respectively. Then
$$
\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}=\frac{97}{2}+\frac{2}{97}=\frac{9413}{194} .
$$

Therefore, the answer is $(B)$.
informal_statement:
30„Éª18 Two prime numbers $p, q$ are exactly the roots of the integer coefficient equation $x^{2}-99 x+m=0$, then the value of $\frac{p}{q}+\frac{q}{p}$ is
(A) 9413.
(B) $\frac{9413}{194}$.
(C) $\frac{9413}{99}$.
(D) $\frac{9413}{97}$.
(E) None of the above answers is correct.
(China Beijing Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1983)

import Mathlib

(A) 9413.
(B) $\frac{9413}{194}$.
(C) $\frac{9413}{99}$.
(D) $\frac{9413}{97}$.
(E) None of the above answers is correct.
(China Beijing Junior High School Mathematics Competition, 1983) -/
theorem algebra_235689 {p q m : ‚Ñï} (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (hroots : p^2 - 99 * p + m = 0 ‚àß q^2 - 99 * q + m = 0)
    (hne : p ‚â† q) : (p / q : ‚Ñù) + q / p = 9413 / 194 := by

informal_statement: Convert the point $\left( 6 \sqrt{3}, \frac{5 \pi}{3}, -2 \right)$ in cylindrical coordinates to rectangular coordinates.
informal_proof:
We are given the cylindrical coordinates $(r, \theta, z)$ where $r = 6\sqrt{3}$, $\theta = \frac{5\pi}{3}$, and $z = -2$. We want to find the corresponding rectangular coordinates $(x, y, z)$, which are defined by the relations $x = r \cos \theta$, $y = r \sin \theta$, and $z = z$. We will show that $x = 3\sqrt{3}$, $y = -9$, and $z = -2$.

First, we compute the value of the $x$-coordinate:
$x = r \cos \theta = (6\sqrt{3}) \cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)$.
To evaluate $\cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)$, we can rewrite the angle as $\frac{5\pi}{3} = 2\pi - \frac{\pi}{3}$. Using the angle subtraction identity for cosine, $\cos(a-b) = \cos a \cos b + \sin a \sin b$, we have:
$$ \cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = \cos\left(2\pi - \frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \cos(2\pi)\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) + \sin(2\pi)\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) $$
Since we know that $\cos(2\pi)=1$, $\sin(2\pi)=0$, and $\cos(\pi/3) = 1/2$, this simplifies to:
$$ \cos\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = (1)\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) + (0)\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \frac{1}{2} $$
Substituting this result back into the expression for $x$:
$$ x = (6\sqrt{3}) \cdot \frac{1}{2} = 3\sqrt{3} $$

Next, we compute the value of the $y$-coordinate:
$y = r \sin \theta = (6\sqrt{3}) \sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right)$.
Using the same angle representation, $\frac{5\pi}{3} = 2\pi - \frac{\pi}{3}$, and the angle subtraction identity for sine, $\sin(a-b) = \sin a \cos b - \cos a \sin b$, we get:
$$ \sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = \sin\left(2\pi - \frac{\pi}{3}\right) = \sin(2\pi)\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) - \cos(2\pi)\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) $$
Since $\sin(2\pi)=0$, $\cos(2\pi)=1$, and $\sin(\pi/3) = \sqrt{3}/2$, this simplifies to:
$$ \sin\left(\frac{5\pi}{3}\right) = (0)\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{3}\right) - (1)\left(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) = -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} $$
Substituting this result back into the expression for $y$:
$$ y = (6\sqrt{3}) \cdot \left(-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) = - \frac{6}{2} \cdot (\sqrt{3} \cdot \sqrt{3}) = -3 \cdot 3 = -9 $$

Finally, the $z$-coordinate is unchanged in the conversion from cylindrical to rectangular coordinates. We are given $z = -2$.

Thus, we have shown that $r \cos \theta = 3\sqrt{3}$, $r \sin \theta = -9$, and $z = -2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Complex Polynomial LinearMap FiniteDimensional Module Module.End
open scoped BigOperators

/- Convert the point $\left( 6 \sqrt{3}, \frac{5 \pi}{3}, -2 \right)$ in cylindrical coordinates to rectangular coordinates. -/
theorem calculus_23145 (r Œ∏ z : ‚Ñù) (hr : r = 6 * Real.sqrt 3) (hŒ∏ : Œ∏ = 5 * Real.pi / 3) (hz : z = -2) :
    r * Real.cos Œ∏ = 3 * Real.sqrt 3 ‚àß r * Real.sin Œ∏ = -9 ‚àß z = -2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Complex Polynomial LinearMap FiniteDimensional Module Module.End
open scoped BigOperators

theorem calculus_23145 (r Œ∏ z : ‚Ñù) (hr : r = 6 * Real.sqrt 3) (hŒ∏ : Œ∏ = 5 * Real.pi / 3) (hz : z = -2) :
    r * Real.cos Œ∏ = 3 * Real.sqrt 3 ‚àß r * Real.sin Œ∏ = -9 ‚àß z = -2 := by 
  have hr_eq : r = 6 * Real.sqrt 3 := hr
  have ht_eq : Œ∏ = 5 * Real.pi / 3 := hŒ∏
  have hz_eq : z = -2 := hz
  
  have hx : r * Real.cos Œ∏ = 3 * Real.sqrt 3 := by
    rw [hr_eq, ht_eq]
    have hcos : Real.cos (5 * Real.pi / 3) = 1 / 2 := by 
      have h1 : 5 * Real.pi / 3 = 2 * Real.pi - Real.pi / 3 := by 
        linarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [Real.cos_sub, Real.cos_two_pi, Real.sin_two_pi]
      have h2 : Real.cos (Real.pi / 3) = 1 / 2 := Real.cos_pi_div_three
      have h3 : Real.sin (Real.pi / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := Real.sin_pi_div_three
      rw [h2, h3]
      ring_nf 
    rw [hcos]
    ring
  have hy : r * Real.sin Œ∏ = -9 := by 
    rw [hr_eq, ht_eq]
    have hsin : Real.sin (5 * Real.pi / 3) = - Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := by
      have h1 : 5 * Real.pi / 3 = 2 * Real.pi - Real.pi / 3 := by
        linarith [Real.pi_pos]
      rw [h1]
      rw [Real.sin_sub, Real.sin_two_pi, Real.cos_two_pi]
      have h2 : Real.sin (Real.pi / 3) = Real.sqrt 3 / 2 := Real.sin_pi_div_three
      have h3 : Real.cos (Real.pi / 3) = 1 / 2 := Real.cos_pi_div_three
      rw [h2, h3]
      ring_nf 
    rw [hsin]
    have h4 : Real.sqrt 3 ^ 2 = 3 := Real.sq_sqrt (show (0 : ‚Ñù) ‚â§ 3 by norm_num)
    nlinarith [Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (3 : ‚Ñù) > 0 by norm_num), h4]
  
  exact ‚ü®hx, hy, hz_eq‚ü©

soln_description:
Solve by eliminating the denominator, and organize into an equation about $x$: $(2 y-1) x^{2}+2(y+1) x+(y+3)=0$. When $x=-\frac{7}{6}$, $y=\frac{1}{2}$; when $y \neq \frac{1}{2}$, it is clear that the above quadratic equation has real roots. Then
$$
\Delta=[2(y+1)]^{2}-4(2 y-1)(y+3) \geqslant 0, y \in[-4,1]
$$

and when $x=-\frac{1}{3}$, $y=-4$; when $x=-2$, $y=1$, so $y_{\text {min }}=-4, y_{\text {max }}=1$
informal_statement: Example 6 Find the maximum and minimum values of the function $y=\frac{x^{2}-2 x-3}{2 x^{2}+2 x+1}$.
informal_proof:
Let the function `f` be defined for all real numbers `x` as `f(x) = (x^2 - 2x - 3) / (2x^2 + 2x + 1)`. We want to show that -4 is the minimum value of `f` and 1 is the maximum value of `f`.

We will prove this in two parts.

**Part 1: -4 is the minimum value.**

To show that -4 is the minimum value, we must prove two things: first, that -4 is in the range of `f`, and second, that -4 is a lower bound for the range of `f`.

1.  First, we show that -4 is in the range of `f`. We can see that for `x = -1/3`:
    `f(-1/3) = ((-1/3)^2 - 2(-1/3) - 3) / (2(-1/3)^2 + 2(-1/3) + 1)`
    `= (1/9 + 2/3 - 3) / (2/9 - 2/3 + 1)`
    `= ((1 + 6 - 27)/9) / ((2 - 6 + 9)/9)`
    `= (-20/9) / (5/9)`
    `= -4`
    Since `f(-1/3) = -4`, the value -4 is in the range of `f`.

2.  Next, we show that `f(x) ‚â• -4` for all `x ‚àà ‚Ñù`. The denominator of `f(x)` is `2x^2 + 2x + 1`. We can rewrite this as `x^2 + (x^2 + 2x + 1) = x^2 + (x+1)^2`. Since `x^2 ‚â• 0` and `(x+1)^2 ‚â• 0`, and they cannot both be zero simultaneously, their sum is strictly positive. Therefore, `2x^2 + 2x + 1 > 0` for all `x ‚àà ‚Ñù`.

    Since the denominator is positive, the inequality `(x^2 - 2x - 3) / (2x^2 + 2x + 1) ‚â• -4` is equivalent to:
    `x^2 - 2x - 3 ‚â• -4(2x^2 + 2x + 1)`
    `x^2 - 2x - 3 ‚â• -8x^2 - 8x - 4`
    `9x^2 + 6x + 1 ‚â• 0`
    This can be factored as `(3x + 1)^2 ‚â• 0`. This inequality is true for all real numbers `x`, since the square of any real number is non-negative.

Since -4 is in the range of `f` and is a lower bound for the range, -4 is the minimum value of `f`.

**Part 2: 1 is the maximum value.**

To show that 1 is the maximum value, we must prove that 1 is in the range of `f` and that it is an upper bound for the range.

1.  First, we show that 1 is in the range of `f`. For `x = -2`:
    `f(-2) = ((-2)^2 - 2(-2) - 3) / (2(-2)^2 + 2(-2) + 1)`
    `= (4 + 4 - 3) / (2(4) - 4 + 1)`
    `= 5 / (8 - 4 + 1)`
    `= 5 / 5`
    `= 1`
    Since `f(-2) = 1`, the value 1 is in the range of `f`.

2.  Next, we show that `f(x) ‚â§ 1` for all `x ‚àà ‚Ñù`. As established before, the denominator `2x^2 + 2x + 1` is always positive. Thus, the inequality `(x^2 - 2x - 3) / (2x^2 + 2x + 1) ‚â§ 1` is equivalent to:
    `x^2 - 2x - 3 ‚â§ 2x^2 + 2x + 1`
    `0 ‚â§ x^2 + 4x + 4`
    This can be factored as `0 ‚â§ (x + 2)^2`. This inequality is true for all real numbers `x`, since the square of any real number is non-negative.

Since 1 is in the range of `f` and is an upper bound for the range, 1 is the maximum value of `f`.

Thus, we have shown that -4 is the minimum value and 1 is the maximum value of the function.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 6 Find the maximum and minimum values of the function $y=\frac{x^{2}-2 x-3}{2 x^{2}+2 x+1}$. -/
theorem algebra_146997 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = Œª x => (x^2 - 2 * x - 3) / (2 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1)) :
    IsLeast (range f) (-4) ‚àß IsGreatest (range f) 1 :=
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem algebra_146997 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : f = Œª x => (x^2 - 2 * x - 3) / (2 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1)) :
    IsLeast (range f) (-4) ‚àß IsGreatest (range f) 1 := by
  have h1 : ‚àÄ x, f x = (x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 3) / (2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1) := by
    intro x
    rw [hf]
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Show that -4 is the least element in the range of f
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- First, show that -4 is in the range of f
      use -1 / 3
      rw [h1]
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Now, we must prove that -4 is indeed the least element
      intro y
      rintro ‚ü®x, hx‚ü©
      rw [h1] at hx
      have h2 : 2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1 > 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg x, sq_nonneg (x + 1)]
      have h3 : (x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 3) / (2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1) ‚â• -4 := by
        have h4 : 2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1 > 0 := h2
        apply (le_div_iff‚ÇÄ h4).mpr
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * 3 + 1)]
      linarith
  ¬∑ -- Show that 1 is the greatest element in the range of f
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- First, show that 1 is in the range of f
      use -2
      rw [h1]
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Now, we must prove that 1 is indeed the greatest element
      intro y
      rintro ‚ü®x, hx‚ü©
      rw [h1] at hx
      have h2 : 2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1 > 0 := by
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg x, sq_nonneg (x + 1)]
      have h3 : (x ^ 2 - 2 * x - 3) / (2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1) ‚â§ 1 := by
        have h4 : 2 * x ^ 2 + 2 * x + 1 > 0 := h2
        apply (div_le_iff‚ÇÄ h4).mpr
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x + 2)]
      linarith

soln_description:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\text { 4. }(1+x)(1+y) \geqslant 2(x+y) \Leftrightarrow 1+x+y+x y \geqslant 2(x+y) \Leftrightarrow 1-x-y+ \\
x y \geqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow(1-x)(1-y) \geqslant 0
\end{array}$$

Similarly,
$$\begin{array}{l}
(1+y)(1+z) \geqslant 2(y+z) \\
(1+z)(1+x) \geqslant 2(z+x)
\end{array}$$

Multiplying the above three inequalities and taking the square root, we get
$$(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) \geqslant \sqrt{8(x+y)(y+z)(z+x)}$$
informal_statement: 4. Let $x, y, z \in [0,1]$, prove that: $(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) \geqslant \sqrt{8(x+y)(y+z)(z+x)}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Let $x, y, z \in [0,1]$, prove that: $(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) \geqslant \sqrt{8(x+y)(y+z)(z+x)}$. -/
theorem inequalities_597126 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1) (hy : y ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1) (hz : z ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1) :
    (1 + x) * (1 + y) * (1 + z) ‚â• Real.sqrt (8 * (x + y) * (y + z) * (z + x)) := by

soln_description:
Answer: 10100.

Solution. Squaring the expression $a^{2}=a+100$, we get $a^{4}=a^{2}+200a+10000=a+100+200a+10000=201a+10100$. From this, we obtain the answer.
informal_statement: 9.2. The number $a$ is a root of the quadratic equation $x^{2}-x-100=0$. Find the value of $a^{4}-201 a$
informal_proof:
Let $a$ be a real number that is a root of the equation $x^2 - x - 100 = 0$. This means we are given the equality:
$$a^2 - a - 100 = 0$$
We wish to find the value of the expression $a^4 - 201a$.

First, we can rearrange the given equation to express $a^2$ in terms of $a$. By adding $a + 100$ to both sides, we obtain:
$$a^2 = a + 100$$
We will use this identity to simplify higher powers of $a$.

Next, let's derive an expression for $a^4$. We can do this through a series of algebraic steps:
\begin{align*}
a^4 &= (a^2)^2 && \text{(by definition of the fourth power)} \\
    &= (a + 100)^2 && \text{(substituting } a^2 = a + 100\text{)} \\
    &= a^2 + 2(a)(100) + 100^2 && \text{(expanding the square)} \\
    &= a^2 + 200a + 10000 \\
    &= (a + 100) + 200a + 10000 && \text{(substituting } a^2 = a + 100 \text{ again)} \\
    &= (a + 200a) + (100 + 10000) && \text{(grouping like terms)} \\
    &= 201a + 10100
\end{align*}
Thus, we have shown that $a^4 = 201a + 10100$.

Now, we can substitute this result into the expression we want to evaluate.
$$a^4 - 201a = (201a + 10100) - 201a$$
Simplifying the right-hand side, we get:
$$a^4 - 201a = 10100$$
Therefore, the value of the expression is 10100.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9.2. The number $a$ is a root of the quadratic equation $x^{2}-x-100=0$. Find the value of $a^{4}-201 a$ -/
theorem algebra_232205 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x^2 - x - 100 = 0) : x^4 - 201 * x = 10100 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_232205 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x^2 - x - 100 = 0) : x^4 - 201 * x = 10100 := by
  have h1 : x^2 = x + 100 := by
    linarith

  have h3 : x^4 = 201 * x + 10100 := by
    calc
      x^4 = (x^2)^2 := by ring
      _ = (x + 100)^2 := by rw [h1]
      _ = x^2 + 200 * x + 10000 := by ring
      _ = (x + 100) + 200 * x + 10000 := by rw [h1]
      _ = 201 * x + 10100 := by ring

  rw [h3]
  all_goals linarith

soln_description:
20. Answer: 21
Solution. Let $d$ be the greatest common divisor (gcd) of these 13 distinct positive integers. Then these 13 integers can be represented as $d a_{1}, d a_{2}, \cdots, d a_{13}$, where $\operatorname{god}\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{13}\right)=$ 1. Let $S$ denote $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{13}$. Then $S d=2142$. In order for $d$ to be the largest possible, $S$ must be the smallest. Since $S \geq 1+2+3+\cdots+13=91$ and that $S$ divides 2142 , and that $2142=2 \times 3 \times 7 \times 51$, the smallest possible value of $S$ can be $2 \times 51=102$, and the largest value of $d$ is thus 21 . By choosing $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \cdots, a_{12}, a_{13}\right)=(1,2,3, \cdots, 12,24)$, we conclude that $d=21$ is possible.
informal_statement: 20. We can find sets of 13 distinct positive integers that add up to 2142. Find the largest possible greatest common divisor of these 13 distinct positive integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 20. We can find sets of 13 distinct positive integers that add up to 2142. Find the largest possible greatest common divisor of these 13 distinct positive integers. -/
theorem number_theory_101887 (S : Finset ‚Ñï) (hS : S.card = 13) (hS1 : ‚àë x ‚àà S, x = 2142) :
    S.gcd id ‚â§ 21 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let the speed of the first car be $v_{1}$ kilometers per hour, and the speed of the second car be $v_{2}$ kilometers per hour. The first car traveled $3 v_{1}$ kilometers before the meeting, and the second car traveled $3 v_{2}$ kilometers. After the meeting, the first car traveled for $\frac{3 v_{2}}{v_{1}}$ hours, and the second car for $\frac{3 v_{1}}{v_{2}}$ hours.

According to the condition, we have:

$$
\frac{3 v_{2}}{v_{1}}-\frac{3 v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\frac{11}{10}
$$

To solve this equation, let $\frac{v_{2}}{v_{1}}=x$. Then $\frac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\frac{1}{x}, 3 x-\frac{3}{x}=\frac{11}{10}$, or $30 x^{2}-11 x-30=0$. The condition of the problem is satisfied only by the positive root $x=\frac{6}{5}, \frac{v_{2}}{v_{1}}=\frac{6}{5}$.

Answer: 1.2 times.

Remark 1. The question to the problem is better formulated as: ‚ÄúFind the ratio of the speeds of the cars.‚Äù

Remark 2. After problem 29(1105), it is advisable to solve problem 1005 from [2].

30(1106). The ore mined in a quarry can be hauled out by the first truck 3 hours faster than by the second truck. If one-third of the ore is hauled out by the first truck and the remaining part by the second truck, it will take $7 \frac{1}{3}$ hours longer than if both trucks worked simultaneously. How many hours can each truck haul out the ore?

Solution. Let the first truck haul out the ore in $t$ hours, then the second truck will take $(t+3)$ hours. In 1 hour, the first truck can haul $\frac{1}{t}$ part, and the second truck $\frac{1}{t+3}$ part of the ore mined in the quarry. When working simultaneously, in 1 hour the trucks can haul $\frac{2 t+3}{t(t+3)}\left(\frac{1}{t}+\frac{1}{t+3}=\frac{2 t+3}{t(t+3)}\right)$ part of the ore, spending $\frac{t(t+3)}{2 t+3}$ hours on the entire work $\left(1: \frac{2 t+3}{t(t+3)}=\frac{t(t+3)}{2 t+3}\right)$.

The first truck can haul $\frac{1}{3}$ part of the ore in $\frac{1}{3}$ hours, and the remaining part $\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)$ the second truck can haul in $\frac{2 t+6}{3}$ hours $\left(\frac{2}{3}: \frac{1}{t+3}=\frac{2 t+6}{3}\right)$.

According to the condition of the problem, we form the equation:

$$
\frac{t}{3}+\frac{2 t+6}{3}=\frac{t(t+3)}{2 t+3}+\frac{22}{3}
$$

from which $3 t^{2}-32 t-48=0, \quad t_{1}=12, \quad t_{2}=-\frac{4}{3}$. The condition of the problem is satisfied only by the positive root of the equation: $t=12$, $t+3=15$.

Answer: in 12 hours and 15 hours.

Remark. It is useful to check the solution according to the condition of the problem.

31(1107). Two mechanics received a task. For its completion, the first mechanic would need 7 hours more than the second. After both mechanics completed half of the task, the work had to be finished by the second mechanic alone, and the task was completed 4.5 hours later than if they had completed the entire task together. How many hours could each mechanic complete the task?

Solution. Let the first mechanic need $t$ hours to complete the task, and the second $(t-7)$ hours. In 1 hour, the first mechanic can complete $\frac{1}{t}$ part of the task, and the second $\frac{1}{t-7}$ part. When working simultaneously, in 1 hour both mechanics can complete $\frac{2 t-7}{t(t-7)}$ part of the task $\left(\frac{1}{t}+\frac{1}{t-7}=\frac{2 t-7}{t(t-7)}\right)$, spending $\frac{t(t-7)}{2 t-7}$ hours on the entire work $\left(1: \frac{2 t-7}{t(t-7)}=\frac{t(t-7)}{2 t-7}\right)$.

For half of the task, both mechanics working together spent $\frac{t(t-7)}{2(2 t-7)}$ hours, and the second mechanic spent $\frac{t-7}{2}$ hours on the remaining half of the task.

According to the condition of the problem, we form the equation:

$$
\frac{t(t-7)}{2(2 t-7)}+\frac{t-7}{2}=\frac{t(t-7)}{2 t-7}+\frac{9}{2}
$$

from which

$$
t^{2}-32 t+112=0, t_{1}=28, t_{2}=4
$$

The root $t_{2}=4$ does not satisfy the condition of the problem, as $t_{2}-7<0$. Therefore, the first mechanic can complete the task in 28 hours, and the second in 21 hours $(28-7=21)$.

Answer: in 28 hours and 21 hours.

Remark. It is advisable to check the solution according to the condition of the problem.

32(1108). A two-digit number is given. The number of its units is 3 less than the number of tens. The product of this number and the number written with the same digits in reverse order is 574. Find the given number.

Solution. Let the number of units of the desired number be $x$, and the number of tens be $x+3$. Then the desired number is $10(x+3)+x$. According to the condition, we have:

$$
(10(x+3)+x)(10 x+x+3)=574 \text {, or } x^{2}+3 x-4=0 \text {, }
$$

from which $x=1$. (The negative root $x=-4$ does not satisfy the condition of the problem.) The desired number is $41(10 \cdot 4+1=41)$.

By checking, we easily see that the problem is solved correctly: $41 \cdot 14=574$.

Answer: 41
informal_statement: 29(1105). Two cars set off simultaneously from $A$ to $B$ and from $B$ to $A$, and they met after 3 hours. The first car arrived in $B$ 1.1 hours later than the second car arrived in $A$. How many times greater is the speed of the second car compared to the speed of the first car?

informal_statement: Two cars, Car A and Car B, travel back and forth continuously between cities $A$ and $B$. Car A departs from city $A$, and Car B departs from city $B$, starting 1 hour earlier than Car A. The two cars meet for the first time at point $C$, which is 200 kilometers from city $A$ and 240 kilometers from city $B$. After the meeting, Car B changes to Car A's speed, while Car A increases its speed. The two cars meet again at point $C$. If Car A then increases its speed by 5 km/h and Car B increases its speed by 50 km/h, the two cars meet again at point $C$. Find the initial speed of Car B.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Two cars, Car A and Car B, travel back and forth continuously between cities $A$ and $B$. Car A departs from city $A$, and Car B departs from city $B$, starting 1 hour earlier than Car A. The two cars meet for the first time at point $C$, which is 200 kilometers from city $A$ and 240 kilometers from city $B$. After the meeting, Car B changes to Car A's speed, while Car A increases its speed. The two cars meet again at point $C$. If Car A then increases its speed by 5 km/h and Car B increases its speed by 50 km/h, the two cars meet again at point $C$. Find the initial speed of Car B. -/
theorem algebra_1250 (a b d t1 t2 t3: ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h1 : t1 = d / a) (h2 : t2 = d / b) (h3 : t3 = d / (a + 5)) (h4 : t3 = d / (b + 50))
    (h5 : d = 200 + 240) :
    b = 80 := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given expression:
   \[
   \lim_{n \to \infty} n \left( \frac{\pi}{4} - n \int_0^1 \frac{x^n}{1+x^{2n}} \, dx \right)
   \]
   We need to show that this limit equals \(\int_0^1 f(x) \, dx\), where \(f(x) = \frac{\arctan x}{x}\) for \(x \in (0,1]\) and \(f(0) = 1\).

2. Consider the integral inside the limit:
   \[
   n \int_0^1 \frac{x^n}{1+x^{2n}} \, dx
   \]
   We can rewrite this integral using a substitution. Let \(u = x^n\), then \(du = nx^{n-1} dx\) and \(dx = \frac{du}{n x^{n-1}} = \frac{du}{n u^{\frac{n-1}{n}}}\).

3. Substituting \(u = x^n\) into the integral, we get:
   \[
   \int_0^1 \frac{x^n}{1+x^{2n}} \, dx = \int_0^1 \frac{u^{\frac{1}{n}}}{1+u^2} \cdot \frac{du}{n u^{\frac{n-1}{n}}} = \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \frac{u^{\frac{1}{n}}}{1+u^2} \cdot u^{-\frac{n-1}{n}} \, du = \frac{1}{n} \int_0^1 \frac{u}{1+u^2} \, du
   \]

4. The integral \(\int_0^1 \frac{u}{1+u^2} \, du\) can be evaluated by recognizing it as a standard integral:
   \[
   \int_0^1 \frac{u}{1+u^2} \, du = \left. \frac{1}{2} \ln(1+u^2) \right|_0^1 = \frac{1}{2} \ln(2)
   \]

5. Therefore, we have:
   \[
   n \int_0^1 \frac{x^n}{1+x^{2n}} \, dx = \frac{1}{n} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \ln(2) = \frac{\ln(2)}{2n}
   \]

6. Now, consider the original limit:
   \[
   \lim_{n \to \infty} n \left( \frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{\ln(2)}{2n} \right) = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left( n \cdot \frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{\ln(2)}{2} \right)
   \]

7. As \(n \to \infty\), the term \(n \cdot \frac{\pi}{4}\) dominates, and the limit simplifies to:
   \[
   \lim_{n \to \infty} \left( n \cdot \frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{\ln(2)}{2} \right) = \infty
   \]

8. However, we need to consider the correct form of the integral and the dominated convergence theorem. The correct approach involves recognizing that:
   \[
   \lim_{n \to \infty} \int_0^1 \frac{\arctan u}{u^{1-\frac{1}{n}}} \, du = \int_0^1 \frac{\arctan u}{u} \, du
   \]
   by the Lebesgue Dominated Convergence Theorem.

9. Therefore, the limit is:
   \[
   \int_0^1 \frac{\arctan x}{x} \, dx
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \int_0^1 \frac{\arctan x}{x} \, dx } \)
informal_statement:
Prove that \[ \lim_{n \to \infty} n \left( \frac{\pi}{4} - n \int_0^1 \frac{x^n}{1+x^{2n}} \, dx \right) = \int_0^1 f(x) \, dx ,  \] where $f(x) = \frac{\arctan x}{x}$ if $x \in \left( 0,1 \right]$ and $f(0)=1$.

[i]Dorin Andrica, Mihai Piticari[/i]

[i]Dorin Andrica, Mihai Piticari[/i] -/

soln_description:
Proof Note that,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Equation (4) } \Leftrightarrow 2 \sum a \leqslant \sum \frac{2 a b}{a+b}+\sum \frac{a b}{c} \\
\Leftrightarrow \sum\left(\frac{a+b}{2}-\frac{2 a b}{a+b}\right) \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \sum\left(\frac{a b}{c}+\frac{b c}{a}-2 b\right) \\
\Leftrightarrow \sum \frac{(a-b)^{2}}{2(a+b)} \leqslant \sum \frac{c(a-b)^{2}}{2 a b} \\
\Leftrightarrow \sum\left(\frac{c}{a b}-\frac{1}{a+b}\right)(a-b)^{2} \geqslant 0 .
\end{array}
$$

Assume without loss of generality that $a \geqslant b \geqslant c$. Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
S_{b}=\frac{b}{c a}-\frac{1}{c+a} \geqslant \frac{1}{a}-\frac{1}{c+a} \geqslant 0, \\
S_{a}=\frac{a}{b c}-\frac{1}{b+c} \geqslant \frac{1}{b}-\frac{1}{b+c} \geqslant 0, \\
S_{b}+S_{c}=\left(\frac{b}{c a}-\frac{1}{c+a}\right)+\left(\frac{c}{a b}-\frac{1}{a+b}\right) \\
=\left(\frac{c}{a b}+\frac{b}{c a}\right)-\frac{1}{c+a}-\frac{1}{a+b} \\
\geqslant \frac{2}{a}-\frac{1}{c+a}-\frac{1}{a+b}>0 .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the original inequality holds.

soln_description:
Solution. The equation is equivalently written as $2^{\sin ^{4} x+\sin ^{2} x}-2^{\cos ^{4} x+\cos ^{2} x}=2 \cos 2 x$. Let's observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos ^{4} x+\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{4} x-\sin ^{2} x & =\left(\cos ^{2} x+\sin ^{2} x\right)\left(\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{2} x\right)+\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{2} x \\
& =2 \cos 2 x
\end{aligned}
$$

and the equation becomes $2^{\sin ^{4} x+\sin ^{2} x}+\sin ^{4} x+\sin ^{2} x=2^{\cos ^{4} x+\cos ^{2} x}+\cos ^{4} x+\cos ^{2} x$.

3 points

1 point

The function $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}, f(t)=2^{t}+t$ is strictly increasing, hence injective.

2 points

thus we obtain $\sin ^{4} x+\sin ^{2} x=\cos ^{4} x+\cos ^{2} x$, i.e., $2 \cos 2 x=0$, with solutions $x \in\left\{\left.\frac{(2 k+1) \pi}{4} \right\rvert\, k \in \mathbb{Z}\right\} \ldots 1$ point
